qas.question: When did Watt finish the development of his improvements to Newcomen's engine?
What did Watt add to Newcomen's engine between 1763 and 1775?
Compared to Smeaton's improvement on Newcomen's engine, how much coal did Watt's engine use?
In addition to Watt, Boulton and Smeaton, whose engine was an atmosphere design?
In an atmospheric engine, what does air pressure push against?
When did Watt finish the development of his improvements to engine cylinders?
What did Newcomen add to Wat's engine between 1763 and 1775?
Compared to Smeaton's improvements on Newcomen's engine, how much steam did Watt's engine use?
In addition to Watt, Boulton, and Smeaton, whose engine was a partial condenser design?
In a condenser engine, what does air pressure push against?

context: The next major step occurred when James Watt developed (<a0_1>1763–<a0_0><a0_2><a0_3><b5_0>1775<b5_0/><a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>) an improved version of Newcomen's engine, with <a1_1><a1_3>a separate <a1_0><a1_2><b6_0>condenser<b6_0/><a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>. Boulton and Watt's early engines used <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><a2_3><b7_0>half<b7_0/><a2_3/><a2_0/> as much<a2_1/> coal<a2_2/> as John Smeaton's improved version of <a3_0>Newcomen's<a3_0/>. <a3_1><a3_2><a3_3><b8_0>Newcomen<a3_3/>'s<b8_0/><a3_1/> and Watt's<a3_2/> early engines were "atmospheric". They were powered by air pressure pushing <a4_1><a4_3>a <a4_0><a4_2><b9_0>piston<b9_0/><a4_3/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> into the partial vacuum generated by condensing steam, instead of the pressure of expanding steam. The engine cylinders had to be large because the only usable force acting on them was due to atmospheric pressure.
